reasoning: The critique mainly targets an alleged downstream policy takeaway (“compromise is a myth, so don’t try”) and argues that compromise is instrumentally stabilizing against lock-in. But the position itself is largely about eutopia being a narrow/fragile target under many moral views (value fragility, multiplicative factors, bounded/unbounded value functions) and explicitly leaves compromise/convergence to a later essay while noting such forces could guide society to eutopia. So the attacked claim is only loosely connected to the essay’s core thesis (moderate-low centrality). Even if the critique’s sociopolitical mechanism were right, it doesn’t substantially refute the essay’s main argument that mostly-great futures are rare absent deliberate optimization (low strength). Many statements are plausible but speculative and attributive (claims about policymakers’ absorption/cascades), and it overstates what the paper “missed” given the paper’s own caveats (moderate correctness). The argument is clear, focused, and contains little fluff (high clarity, low dead weight), and it largely sticks to a single line of critique (high single-issue). Overall it poses a limited problem for the position as written.
title: Overgeneralizing moral disagreement makes compromise seem futile, fueling polarization and coordination failure
